data.title: The dynamics of cyber conflict between rival antagonists, 2001-11
data.abstractNote: This article offers the first large-scale empirical portrait of state-driven cyber conflict by systematically cataloguing and analysing cyber incidents and disputes among international rivals from 2001 to 2011. Arguing that discussions of cyberwar and cyber conflict have been dominated by speculative and sensationalist accounts, Valeriano and Maness return the debate to social science by constructing and examining a dataset of 110 discrete cyber incidents clustered into 45 cyber disputes across 126 active rival dyads. They define cyber incidents as individual malicious operations—ranging from website defacements and distributed denial-of-service attacks to data theft—launched by one state against another, and cyber disputes as campaigns comprising one or more related incidents over a given time period. Drawing on rivalry literature, deterrence theory, and theories of restraint and regionalism, they hypothesize that contrary to the popular perception of unbounded cyber aggression, states will demonstrate restraint in their use of cyber tactics and that cyber conflict will be geographically constrained to rival pairs with existing histories of tension. Using rigorous open-source coding procedures, each incident is coded for initiator, target, tactic, severity, and timing. Quantitative analysis reveals that only 20 of the 126 rival dyads engaged in any cyber conflict during the decade under study, and those that did averaged just three incidents per dyad. The most active dyad, the United States and China, accounts for 22 of the 110 incidents within five disputes, yet even this pair refrains from the most destructive forms of cyber operations. The overwhelming majority of incidents are low-intensity interactions—chiefly defacements, probes, and denial-of-service campaigns—that do not escalate into kinetic violence. The authors identify a pattern of ‘cyber restraint,’ whereby states refrain from targeting critical infrastructure or employing destructive malware, motivated by fears of retaliation, uncontrolled escalation, collateral damage and erosion of international norms. They also demonstrate pronounced regionalism: most cyber disputes occur among neighboring adversaries, notably post-Soviet states in Eastern Europe and rivals in South and East Asia, supporting the view that cyberspace does not erase traditional geopolitical constraints. The study acknowledges limitations related to open-source data and attribution challenges, and proposes future research on how emerging cyber capabilities influence the evolution of international norms, the role of non-state actors and proxies in cyber rivalries, and the effects of alliances and third-party interventions on dispute dynamics. By grounding the study of interstate cyber conflict in empirical evidence and rivalry theory, this work provides a nuanced foundation for policymakers seeking proportional and informed responses in cyberspace, rather than reactionary or alarmist measures.

data.title: Organizing for cyberspace operations: selected issues
data.abstractNote: This article investigates how States should organize military cyberspace commands to conduct both offensive and defensive operations in compliance with the law of armed conflict and broader strategic objectives, using the establishment and practices of the United States Cyber Command (USCYBERCOM) as a primary lens. It begins with the historical context of USCYBERCOM’s creation in 2009—merging Joint Task Force-Global Network Operations and Joint Functional Component Command–Network Warfare—driven by recognized gaps in Department of Defense (DoD) network defense and high-profile intrusion events such as Operation Buckshot Yankee. The study maps international responses, noting analogous developments in China, India, Russia, South Korea, Iran, Germany, and the United Kingdom, and underscores the diversity of organizational models emerging worldwide. Part II focuses on the legal vetting of cyberspace capabilities, comparing the U.S. Air Force’s policy of reviewing all cyber tools against the Army and Navy’s effect-based review by which only capabilities with potential lethal or destructive outcomes undergo legal scrutiny. Drawing on DoD policy memoranda, service-level legal review procedures, and perspectives from the Tallinn Manual, the author recommends that States adopt a differentiated review standard calibrated to operational effect, thereby balancing the imperative of legal compliance with the need for rapid capability fielding. Part III addresses precautions against harm to civilian infrastructure, analyzing the feasibility and benefits of maintaining segregated military networks—such as the NIPRnet—distinct from civilian Internet systems to minimize collateral damage, improve attribution, and strengthen legal defensibility of operations. The author contends that virtual and physical network segregation enhances operational security and upholds civilian protection obligations, though it acknowledges challenges posed by shared gateways and chokepoints. Part IV extends this discussion to the conduct of cyber attacks, evaluating proposals like the ‘carpet bomb’ botnet concept, which envisions leveraging .mil infrastructure to generate large-scale denial-of-service effects. While recognizing the technical feasibility of such dedicated offensive architectures, the analysis warns that intermingling military and civilian networks without adequate separation raises serious legal and operational risks under jus in bello. Through these sections, the paper develops a normative framework underscoring three core principles: effect-based legal review of cyber capabilities, virtual or physical segregation of military networks to protect civilian systems, and rigorous evaluation of operational practicability when determining feasible cyber command structures. Limitations stem from sparse publicly available State practice and evolving cyber technologies, yet the author identifies future research avenues—including empirical assessments of segregation efficacy and comparative studies of cyber command doctrines—to refine policy guidelines. Ultimately, the study offers actionable recommendations to ensure that as States organize for cyberspace operations, they remain fully compliant with international law while preserving strategic effectiveness in a rapidly transforming domain of warfare.

data.title: The rules of cyber-welfare: what are the issues with these rules, how can the United States respond to an attack when applying these rules, and should new rules Be enacted
data.abstractNote: This article offers a comprehensive doctrinal analysis of the existing international legal framework governing state conduct in cyberspace, specifically assessing the applicability of the United Nations Charter and the non-binding Tallinn Manual to cyber-warfare and proposing a path toward a binding treaty. Epstein begins by surveying divergent conceptions of cyber-warfare—definitions based variously on the nature of the targeted object, the medium employed, and the syntactic, semantic, or hybrid characteristics of the attacks—and illustrates each category with hypothetical scenarios ranging from denial-of-service operations to semantic manipulation of critical information systems. He then turns to the core provisions of the UN Charter—Article 2(4)’s prohibition on the threat or use of force, Article 51’s right of self-defense, and Articles 41 and 42’s complementary measures—and demonstrates how these rules, crafted for kinetic conflict, struggle to accommodate cyber operations. Epstein examines the interpretive guidance of the Tallinn Manual’s rules on use of force, threat of force, necessity, proportionality, immediacy, collective self-defense, and permissible countermeasures, identifying four principal deficiencies: the misfit of traditional “use of force” and “armed attack” definitions in cyber contexts; the Manual’s unquantified scale-and-effects test; attribution and intent challenges; and the normative ambiguity created by reliance on a non-binding instrument. To remedy these gaps, Epstein advocates convening a U.S.-led international conference to negotiate a binding cyber-warfare treaty that builds upon the substance of the Tallinn Manual while introducing: a sliding-scale and effects test with quantifiable thresholds; explicit consideration of state intent; mandatory multilateral consultations before defensive or counter-cyber actions; illustrative examples to guide interpretation; and a universal obligation, analogous to Article 2(6) of the UN Charter, to ensure compliance by non-signatories to preserve international peace and security. Acknowledging procedural and political hurdles—such as achieving consensus among diverse state actors and keeping pace with rapidly evolving cyber threats—Epstein argues that without a binding instrument, states will continue to grapple with unacceptable legal uncertainty. The article concludes by urging U.S. leadership in treaty negotiations to establish a clear, adaptable, and legally precise regime that balances the flexibility needed to address emergent cyber threats with sufficient precision to deter unlawful cyber-attacks and sustain global stability.

data.title: This means war (maybe) - clarifying casus belli in cyberspace
data.abstractNote: In “This Means War (Maybe) – Clarifying Casus Belli in Cyberspace,” Lieutenant Colonel Charles C. Poche examines the ambiguous threshold at which cyber operations can justifiably trigger a state’s right to self-defense under existing international law. Noting that cyberspace blurs the traditional distinction between espionage and armed attack, Poche argues that the lack of agreed norms governing casus belli in the cyber domain creates a dangerous gray zone that risks inadvertent escalation to armed conflict. Employing a doctrinal legal analysis grounded in the emerging Tallinn Manual framework and case-study methodology, the paper first reviews the prohibition on the use of force in the U.N. Charter and the attendant exception for self-defense. The author then details the Tallinn Manual indicators—state involvement, severity, invasiveness, immediacy, and directness—and applies these factors to two seminal incidents: the 2007 distributed denial-of-service attacks on Estonia and the 2010 Stuxnet operation against Iran. Through comparative analysis, Poche finds that while the Estonian attacks lacked the requisite severity and directness to constitute an armed attack, Stuxnet’s physical effects on Iran’s nuclear infrastructure likely met the threshold for triggering self-defense. Recognizing the expansive intermediate zone between these extremes, the paper offers a five-part framework to reduce legal ambiguity and deter miscalculation. First, it urges the United States to openly acknowledge its justified offensive cyber operations to build transparent state practice. Second, it recommends preserving clear organizational boundaries between cyber attack/defense and espionage functions to safeguard espionage’s status under the law. Third, it advocates asserting sovereign control over designated portions of cyberspace as a bright-line test of invasiveness. Fourth, it calls for deploying active cyber defenses—automated detection, tracing, and counter-strikes—within sovereign cyber territories, drawing a modern parallel to the Caroline standard’s “reflexive” self-defense. Fifth, it proposes routinely reporting active defense deployments to the U.N. Security Council to promote shared understanding of limits and expected responses, thus accelerating the crystallization of customary international law. The paper acknowledges its U.S.-centric focus and the evolving nature of cyber capabilities as limitations and suggests future research comparing these recommendations against other major cyber powers’ doctrines and exploring empirical effects of reporting active defenses on deterrence and norm formation. Poche’s work advances both scholarly and practical policymaking by delineating the contours of cyber casus belli, integrating legal theory with operational considerations, and offering concrete measures to foster clarity and stability in state behavior in cyberspace.

data.title: Conventional military force as a response to cyber capabilities: on sending packets and receiving missles
data.abstractNote: Jason F. Keen’s 2015 article examines whether and under what circumstances states may lawfully employ conventional military force in response to malicious cyber intrusions, a pressing issue amid rapidly evolving cyber capabilities and lagging international legal frameworks. Drawing on a doctrinal legal methodology, Keen analyzes the United Nations Charter’s use-of-force provisions, customary international law, and state practice to clarify whether cyber-only intrusions justify countermeasures or self-defense under Articles 2(4) and 51 of the Charter and the Articles on State Responsibility. He surveys key International Court of Justice judgments—Nicaragua, Congo, Oil Platforms—and Security Council reactions, illustrating the high thresholds the ICJ has set for an “armed attack” and the reluctance of states and international bodies to classify cyber operations as uses of force. Keen identifies a trend in which targeted conventional strikes—cross-border raids in Georgia post-2008, the U.S. cruise missile attack on Iraqi intelligence in 1993, and Israel’s 2014 response to a Syrian missile launch—are tacitly accepted by the Security Council as legitimate countermeasures when cyber or other hostile acts fall below the armed-attack threshold. Through empirical examples, he argues that while few cyber intrusions meet the threshold of armed attack, states nonetheless carve out a “below the line” operational space for proportionate conventional responses, challenging doctrinal claims that the Security Council holds a monopoly on the use of force. Keen warns that this indeterminacy between legal theory and pragmatic state practice risks unregulated escalation and destabilizing precedents, particularly given attribution challenges and inconsistent international practice. Concluding that Security Council authorization for force in cyber-only scenarios is unlikely and ICJ determinations of cyberarmed attacks remain remote, the article offers a nuanced legal framework for understanding when conventional force may serve as a permissible countermeasure to cyber threats. It underscores the need for normative guidelines to reconcile legal doctrines with evolving state practice, propose standardized thresholds for lawful retaliation, and assess the deterrent efficacy of conventional countermeasures in cyber conflict.

data.title: Cyber hostilities and the war powers resolution
data.abstractNote: This article addresses the domestic legal governance of U.S. military offensive cyber operations and examines whether such operations fall within the scope of the War Powers Resolution. Congress, through Section 954 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012, explicitly linked “military activities in cyberspace” to the War Powers Resolution, reflecting congressional intent to subject offensive cyber capabilities to the same checks as traditional kinetic forces. The author, employing a doctrinal, case-based method, analyzes legislative texts, congressional history, executive branch communications, and public reporting to trace how “hostilities” became the operative trigger for statutory reporting and withdrawal requirements under the 1973 Resolution. After reconstructing the four limiting factors articulated by the Departments of Defense and State—scale of engagement, risk of escalation, exposure of U.S. forces, and scope of military means—the article applies this rubric in a detailed case study of the Stuxnet computer virus attack in Iran. This analysis reveals that Stuxnet’s narrowly tailored objective, minimal risk of escalation due to attribution challenges and geographic containment, nonexistent U.S. personnel exposure, and exclusive use of cyber means would likely lead the executive branch to conclude that such an operation does not constitute “hostilities.” Accordingly, the War Powers Resolution’s notification and withdrawal mandates would remain unlikely to constrain stand-alone offensive cyber activities despite explicit congressional linkage. By synthesizing statutory language, executive practice, and a concrete cyber incident, the article uncovers a significant governance gap: under existing executive criteria, offensive military cyber operations consistently fail to reach the threshold of “hostilities” necessary to trigger domestic constitutional checks on the use of force. The author concludes that without revised statutory definitions or new policy mechanisms—whether through amended domestic law or treaty-based models—the War Powers Resolution will continue to exclude a growing class of state-sponsored cyber operations from meaningful democratic oversight, thereby undermining accountability in the digital battlespace. The article calls for future research on comparative legislative approaches and empirical study of executive-legislative interactions in cyber missions to develop more robust oversight frameworks.

data.title: Pouring new wine into old bottles: understanding the notion of direct participation in hostilities within the cyber domain
data.abstractNote: Christopher P. Toscano’s article “Pouring New Wine into Old Bottles: Understanding the Notion of Direct Participation in Hostilities within the Cyber Domain” examines the challenge of applying established International Humanitarian Law (IHL) and the Law of Armed Conflict (LOAC) principles—especially the principle of distinction and Direct Participation in Hostilities (DPH)—to cyber operations. Recognizing that cyber attacks like Stuxnet can produce physical effects and that civilian hackers can operate globally without proximity to the battlefield, Toscano argues that existing legal frameworks, though not explicitly drafted for cyber operations, must nonetheless regulate cyber hostilities until a specialized cyber warfare treaty emerges. He conducts a thorough doctrinal analysis of treaty provisions, customary law scholarship, state practice, opinio juris, and the Tallinn Manual, identifying gaps in current legal thought and proposing a novel framework for determining when a civilian who engages in cyber hostilities forfeits protection and becomes a lawful target. Toscano defines the threshold criteria for cyber-related DPH by analogizing traditional kinetic operations: hostilities encompass acts intended to cause harm to a state’s military or civilian infrastructure, whether through data destruction, denial of service, or manipulation of cyber-physical systems. He outlines three response modalities within self-defense bounds—non-kinetic, kinetic, and covert—each of which must adhere to sovereignty, proportionality, necessity, and the prohibition on unnecessary suffering. For non-kinetic responses, Toscano proposes active cyber defenses that detect and neutralize threats while preserving evidence. In discussing kinetic responses, he clarifies that cyber-enabled physical attacks can be legally analogous to conventional targeting of enemy combatants, though political and escalation risks mandate case-by-case analysis. On covert action, the author explores clandestine operations, including targeted killings, renditions, and cyber operations designed to track or neutralize adversary actors in neutral states, and he addresses the legal constraints posed by Executive Order 12333 and the United Nations Charter. Throughout, Toscano emphasizes the Frankenstein-like national policies that interpret IHL as cyber law, noting that the opacity of many states’ cyber doctrines and classified U.S. authorities underscores the need for transparency. He concludes that, despite divergent state positions and the unlikelihood in the near term of a comprehensive cyber-hostilities treaty, IHL principles, as elaborated in the Tallinn Manual, provide an immediate baseline for regulating cyber warfare. Toscano further argues that consistent state practice and opinio juris will gradually crystallize into customary international law and urges future research into treaty negotiations, the role of regional bodies such as NATO in harmonizing norms, transparent national cyber doctrines, and the refinement of self-defense criteria in preemptive cyber contexts. His proposed DPCH framework offers military and policy-makers a structured approach to classify cyber actors, determine lawful targeting, and select appropriate response options that balance defense imperatives with civilian protection obligations.

data.title: Enhancing international cyber security
data.abstractNote: This article by Sico van der Meer critically examines the challenge of securing the international cyber domain through the lens of diplomacy and normative development, arguing that while national cyber-deterrence strategies may offer short-term gains, they risk provoking an arms race and escalating tensions among state actors. Drawing on qualitative policy analysis, the author reviews official documents, case studies of major cyber incidents—including the Estonia attacks of 2007, Georgia 2008, Iran 2010, and Ukraine 2015—and ongoing multilateral processes such as the United Nations Group of Governmental Experts (UNGGE), the OSCE confidence-building measures (CBMs), and NATO’s Tallinn Manual. Van der Meer first outlines the growing spectrum of cyber threats—from espionage and crime to terrorism and sabotage—and the limitations of passive deterrence through costly defensive investments that may fuel “tit-for-tat” escalation without addressing underlying misperceptions or the absence of binding norms. He then situates diplomacy as a more sustainable mechanism for fostering transparency, predictability, and cooperation in cyberspace. Confidence-building measures, both bilateral and multilateral, are presented as “pressure valves” to defuse tensions, while shared norms and values, though slower to develop, offer powerful invisible restraints analogous to the nuclear non-use taboo. However, the author acknowledges significant obstacles: divergent state conceptions of cyber security, contested views regarding Internet freedom versus state intervention, the involvement of non-state actors such as industry leaders, civil society, and technical experts, and the inherently non-binding nature of CBMs and emerging norms. Despite the protracted pace of diplomatic norm-building relative to rapid technological change, van der Meer documents nascent progress: the UNGGE’s work on responsible state behavior and the application of international law in cyberspace; the ITU’s initiatives on common language and standards; OSCE’s adoption of CBMs; and the positive reception of the Tallinn Manual beyond NATO membership. He concludes that while continued investment in secure cyber infrastructure remains necessary, policy-makers should prioritize and accelerate diplomatic processes to establish enduring confidence and a normative order in cyberspace. The study calls for future research on legally binding cyber treaties, robust compliance and verification regimes, and the role of private actors in norm creation and enforcement, offering a roadmap for transitioning from unilateral deterrence to a cooperative, norm-based international cyber security regime.

data.title: Obligations of states, before, during, and after a cyber security incident
data.abstractNote: This article by Christian Walter critically examines the existing international legal framework governing inter-State “cyber security incidents” that fall below the threshold of armed conflict or use of force, asking how general principles and rules of international law might impose duties on States before, during, and after such incidents. Walter begins by affirming the continued primacy of sovereign territoriality in cyberspace, rejecting the notion of a sui generis legal space divorced from State authority. He defines a “cyber security incident” expansively to encompass a spectrum of malicious cyber operations—from distributed denial of service attacks to industrial espionage and hacktivism—that inflict cross-border harm akin to environmental damage yet do not constitute armed force. This definition situates most cyber events outside the armed conflict paradigm, redirecting attention to preventive and cooperative obligations under general international law. The core of Walter’s inquiry is whether established doctrines—drawn by analogy from environmental law’s principle of good neighbourliness, human rights jurisprudence on positive obligations, and procedural norms in cybercrime treaties—supply a coherent foundation for State duties in cyberspace. He critiques the preventive model: unlike pollution or hazardous environmental activities, cyberspace cannot be neatly partitioned into hazardous versus non-hazardous operations, so pre-incident triggers for preventive duties are impractical. Instead, he argues that the general principle of good neighbourliness offers the most promising normative basis for obligations of cooperation and mutual assistance during and after a cyber security incident. This principle, long applied in environmental law to mitigate transboundary harm, can be adapted to require States to share information, coordinate responses, and render assistance once harmful cyber activity occurs. Walter further proposes that where a malicious operation can be traced to a computer system under a State’s exclusive control, that State bears a human rights–inspired obligation to investigate, akin to duties to inquire into rights abuses in contexts of State detention. He then examines the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime as the leading multilateral instrument creating procedural obligations for data preservation, evidence sharing, and mutual legal assistance. Although its treaty obligations bind only parties, its provisions illustrate how States might operationalize post-incident cooperation, including expedited data preservation, mutual legal assistance, and extradition consultations. Walter concludes that, given the absence of clear preventive thresholds in cyberspace, the focus of international law should shift from pre-incident regulation to reinforcing cooperative and investigative obligations once cyber incidents arise. He acknowledges the exploratory nature of analogical reasoning across legal fields and notes that comprehensive preventive duties and transborder data-access rules await further development. He highlights the ongoing negotiations for an Additional Protocol to the Budapest Convention on transborder data access as a critical frontier for shaping future State obligations. Ultimately, Walter’s analysis maps a preliminary yet structured framework—anchored in good neighbourliness, investigative duties, and cybercrime cooperation mechanisms—to address interstate cyber incidents and fill gaps where no specialized treaty regime yet exists.

data.title: Neutrality in the digital battle space: applications of principle of neutrality in information warfare
data.abstractNote: This article examines the applicability of established international legal frameworks, specifically the 1907 Hague Convention and the Hague Rules Regarding Aerial Warfare, to the emerging domain of information warfare and the principle of neutrality in cyberspace. Against a backdrop of notable incidents—including infiltration of U.S. Department of Defense networks, Stuxnet’s attack on Iran’s nuclear program, and distributed denial-of-service assaults during the Estonian and Georgian conflicts—the author argues that most offensive cyber operations capable of causing harm should be regarded as armed conflict under current international humanitarian law. Through a legal doctrinal analysis informed by treaty text, state practice, and illustrative scenarios, the article identifies the three core duties of neutral states—impartiality, intervention to prevent harm emanating from neutral territory, and repulsion of belligerent forces—and demonstrates how these translate into the digital realm. Neutral states must provide telecommunications services without discrimination, quarantine or disable compromised systems used for attacks, and adopt proactive measures to safeguard critical infrastructure. Failure to do so may permit belligerents to invoke the right of necessity and neutralize offending systems. The study also grapples with challenges unique to cyberspace: difficulties in timely attribution of attacks, uncertainty regarding notification of compromise, and the classification of information operations as armed conflict, espionage, or criminal activity. While certain cyber intrusions, such as data theft, may fall outside the Law of Armed Conflict and be more appropriately addressed through criminal or espionage channels, the authors contend that the majority of high-impact information warfare tactics that risk injury or damage—exploitation, destruction, and disruption of digital systems—demand application of existing LoAC norms. The article further explores scenarios where neutral states inadvertently host digital weapons or permit use of their infrastructure to attack belligerents, concluding that the storage of non-weaponized data backups by private companies does not breach neutrality, whereas failure to intervene against botnets or malware launches does. Recognizing the rapid evolution of cyber capabilities, the author recommends that rather than drafting wholly new treaties, the international community should adapt and refine existing neutrality rules, develop early–warning and deterrent technologies, and cultivate diplomatic consensus to guide state and non-state actors. The article concludes that the extension of current neutrality obligations to the digital battlefield offers a flexible, humane approach to governing cyber conflict, emphasizes the need for international cooperation to address attribution and notification challenges, and calls for empirical research on state practice and private sector roles in information warfare.

data.title: Inverted-militarized-diplomacy: how states bargain with cyber weapons
data.abstractNote: This article addresses a critical gap in the international relations literature by examining how states leverage cyber weapons in diplomatic bargaining, a topic largely overlooked despite the rapid proliferation of military cyber capabilities. Traditional models of militarized interstate bargaining assume that credible threats require visibility and attribution; however, cyber weapons derive their potency from secrecy and deniability. This paradox has led some scholars to dismiss cyber coercion as ineffective or even mythical. Against this backdrop, Richard B. Andres introduces the concept of “inverted-militarized diplomacy,” a framework that reconceptualizes the integration of cyber operations within statecraft. Rather than initiating coercive diplomacy through explicit threats, states employing this inverted approach first execute clandestine cyber intrusions to achieve strategic gains—ranging from economic disruption to information manipulation—and subsequently engage in diplomatic channels to forestall retaliation and manage escalation. Drawing on historical analogues such as piracy and proxy irregular warfare, the author identifies three principal methods of cyber coercion: economic sabotage, political subversion, and critical infrastructure disruption, each facilitated by the plausible deniability inherent in cyber tools. Through conceptual analysis and illustrative case studies—spanning state-sponsored malware deployments, intellectual property theft campaigns, and the covert facilitation of insurgent communications—the article demonstrates how inverted diplomacy allows states to exploit surprise for immediate objectives while preserving strategic ambiguity. This model challenges prevailing theories of deterrence and signaling by showing that the sequence of force and negotiation need not follow conventional patterns. The framework underscores the need for policymakers to anticipate covert cyber operations not as anomalies but as deliberate components of diplomatic strategy. The article concludes by outlining avenues for future research, including empirical validation across diverse geopolitical contexts, exploration of legal implications under jus ad bellum and doctrines of state responsibility, and development of normative and policy instruments to regulate clandestine cyber coercion. Ultimately, inverted-militarized diplomacy provides a novel theoretical lens that situates cyber weapons within a broader repertoire of state strategies, offering both scholars and practitioners insights into the evolving intersection of warfare and diplomacy in the digital age.

data.title: The regulation of the civilian and military realms of cyberspace
data.abstractNote: This article by J. Taylor offers a comprehensive doctrinal analysis of the evolving legal and regulatory challenges arising from the convergence of civilian and military activities in cyberspace. Recognizing cyberspace as an emergent domain of human activity integral to both everyday life and state security, the paper systematically reviews existing international legal instruments—most notably the Additional Protocols to the Geneva Conventions, the law of armed conflict (LOAC), and the Tallinn Manual—to assess their applicability to cyber operations and to highlight critical lacunae. Through examination of real-world incidents, including disruptive attacks on SCADA systems and the rise of ransomware, Taylor demonstrates that traditional principles such as distinction, proportionality, and accountability are severely strained by the borderless, dual-use nature of cyber tools and the diffusion of capabilities among state and non-state actors. The principle of distinction is particularly compromised by the inherent indistinctness of cyber infrastructure, where an operation aimed at a military target often risks civilian harm. Proportionality is further complicated by the cascading, uncontrollable effects of malware once deployed, prompting controversial arguments about human responsibility for unintended consequences. Taylor also critiques the NATO-centric origins of the Tallinn Manual and the limited legitimacy of its norms beyond Western states. In response to these deficiencies, the paper proposes a recalibrated regulatory framework emphasizing proactive legal restraint, clearer criteria for state responsibility, and a normative consensus on weapon classification and civilian participation in hostilities. The author calls for enhanced predictability in cyber regulation through the development of universally accepted definitions and attribution mechanisms and urges empirical research into state practice, the interplay between emerging cyber norms and online freedoms, and legal strategies for countering terrorism-driven cyber operations. Limitations include the Western-centric doctrinal focus and the rapid technological evolution that may outpace legal adaptation. By integrating civilian and military perspectives, this study advances policy discourse and charts pathways toward a more coherent and secure regulatory regime for cyberspace.

data.title: Whither the web? International law, cybersecurity, and critical infrastructure protection
data.abstractNote: In “Whither the Web? International Law, Cybersecurity, and Critical Infrastructure Protection,” David P. Fidler analyzes the adequacy of existing international legal norms and U.S. policy frameworks for defending critical infrastructure against cyber threats, and examines the emerging U.S. strategic turn toward offensive cyber capabilities as a deterrent. Fidler begins by highlighting congressional testimony from Admiral Michael Rogers, Commander of U.S. Cyber Command and Director of the NSA, who underscores that adversarial states and non-state actors can incapacitate U.S. critical infrastructure via networked control systems. Rogers calls for new norms or principles to govern behavior in cyberspace, reflecting a broader demand to strengthen the “web” of international law applicable to cyber threats. Against this backdrop, Fidler maps the normative landscape, noting that although preexisting international law—treaties governing terrorism, armed conflict, and transnational harm—already prohibits most cyber operations against critical infrastructure, these legacy rules were not designed for the cyber context and offer little assurance of compliance or enforcement. He details how existing instruments—the 1998 U.S. Presidential Directive on critical infrastructure protection, the 2013 Framework for Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity, and multilateral conventions such as the Council of Europe’s Cybercrime Convention and the African Union’s Cybersecurity Convention—address discrete sectors but fall short of a cohesive, binding regime. Moreover, Fidler underscores that attempts to develop cyber-specific norms face challenges in securing state agreement, distinguishing new principles from ineffective antecedents, and enforcing compliance against determined violators. Faced with normative uncertainty, U.S. policy has pivoted to material power: Fidler chronicles the 2013 Executive Order on Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity, President Obama’s 2015 sanctions authority targeting malicious cyber actors, and the April 2015 DoD Cyber Strategy, all of which emphasize offensive cyber capabilities and sanctions to deter hostile actions. He observes that this shift reflects a lack of confidence in both existing and prospective norms to safeguard critical infrastructure, prompting reliance on a doctrine of cyber deterrence predicated on threat and use of cyber power rather than international legal restraints. Fidler warns that this nascent approach to deterrence diverges from traditional models, especially nuclear, and its efficacy remains untested. He concludes by offering a conceptual framework of the “web” of international legal norms relevant to cyber-enabled attacks on critical infrastructure, and he calls for future empirical research on the effectiveness of deterrence measures, normative adaptation in non-Western contexts, and the delineation of credible thresholds for cyber coercion and retaliation in a multipolar world. His analysis integrates doctrinal, policy, and strategic dimensions, illuminating why power projection has become central to U.S. cyber defense and why norm development alone may be insufficient to address the persistent threat to vital national systems.

data.title: Cyberspace, non-state actors and the obligation to prevent transboundary harm
data.abstractNote: This article examines the customary international law obligation of states to prevent transboundary harm arising from malicious cyber operations conducted by non-state actors via cyber infrastructure located within their territories. Buchan argues that, in contrast to the contested doctrine of attribution—where states incur responsibility only when they exercise “effective control” over perpetrators—the obligation to prevent hinges on a due diligence standard and does not require precise technical attribution. Drawing on seminal decisions of the International Court of Justice (ICJ) (notably Corfu Channel and Bosnia Genocide), International Law Commission materials, state practice, and scholarly commentary, the article demonstrates that the prevention obligation comprises two distinct duties: an obligation of result and an obligation of conduct. The first duty—an obligation of result—imposes on states a requirement to establish a minimum domestic legal and institutional framework capable of deterring and punishing malicious cyber conduct. While states retain broad discretion regarding the design of these frameworks, they must adopt legislation, regulatory regimes, and law-enforcement or cyber incident response capacities sufficient to guard against cyber threats emanating from their jurisdiction. The second duty—an obligation of conduct—applies when states have actual or constructive knowledge of a specific threat. Under a due diligence standard, states must act reasonably, employing available resources to suppress or mitigate the threat; what is “reasonable” depends on the state’s capacity, the nature of the threat, and the risks involved. The article highlights two limiting factors: the wide margin of appreciation in domestic measures leads to uneven prevention capabilities, and a capacity-sensitive due diligence standard may incentivize forum-shopping by attackers exploiting weaker states. Buchan concludes that while the customary prevention obligation offers a valuable legal tool that operates independently of precise attribution and applies even when malicious traffic merely transits a state’s infrastructure, its current breadth and flexibility are insufficient to ensure uniform protection. He proposes that binding treaty law could “upgrade” state obligations by prescribing specific procedural and substantive measures—such as cybercrime statutes, regulatory oversight of ICT providers, creation of national Computer Emergency Response Teams, and mandatory 24/7 points of contact—and by establishing supranational institutions to facilitate prospective cooperation, capacity building, and information-sharing. Future research should explore treaty design for enhancing due diligence standards, empirical assessments of state capacities, and non-state actor routing strategies to inform more coherent and equitable prevention norms in cyberspace.

data.title: Expertise, uncertainty, and international law: a study of the Tallinn manual on cyberwarfare
data.abstractNote: This article examines how international legal expertise is mobilized to articulate the scope and meaning of existing norms in light of emerging forms of cyber conflict. Focusing on the Tallinn Manual on Cyberwarfare—an expert report commissioned by NATO—the authors analyze how expert discourse addresses uncertainties inherent in applying the jus ad bellum and jus in bello frameworks of international law to cyber operations. Drawing on interpretive qualitative methods, Kessler and Werner trace the institutional role of expert commissions in constructing “institutional facts” and normative interpretations through analogical reasoning, legal definitions, and contextual factors. They emphasize the dual function of expertise: to absorb uncertainty by formulating analogies such as the International Court of Justice’s “scale and effects” test from Nicaragua, and to produce new indeterminacies by relativizing core legal concepts and exposing fractures among experts. The article highlights the Manual’s invocation of factors like severity, invasiveness, state involvement, and the prevailing political environment to guide assessments of whether cyberattacks constitute prohibited uses of force under Article 2(4) of the UN Charter. Although these factors aim to reduce ambiguity, their empirical grounding rests on the intuitions and reputations of individual experts rather than opinio juris of states, raising questions about the legitimacy and authority of such expert-led frameworks. Moreover, the Manual officially records instances of expert dissent on foundational issues—including the qualification of cyber operations as armed attacks, the threshold for applying the laws of armed conflict, and the distinction between international and non-international armed conflict—thereby solidifying uncertainties rather than resolving them. Kessler and Werner argue that legal expertise functions as the strategic management of uncertainty: experts not only interpret law but also co-constitute the problem space by framing cyber threats, selecting analogies, and incorporating risk-based considerations into legal reasoning. This process transforms unstructured uncertainty about cyber operations into structured but contested legal norms, cementing expert authority while institutionalizing indeterminacy. Concluding that the proliferation and specialization of international legal instruments have made legal experts indispensable, the authors call for critical scrutiny of expert commissions in conflict and security law. They suggest further comparative research into how different expert bodies articulate norms amid evolving security challenges and empirical studies on how states incorporate, contest, or resist expert-produced interpretations in their legal positions and policy practices. By situating cybersecurity within broader dynamics of legal fragmentation, professional bias, and the politics of uncertainty, the study sheds light on the co-constitution of legal expertise and cyber conflict in contemporary international relations.

data.title: The Kampala compromise and cyberattacks: can there Be an international crime of cyber-aggression
data.abstractNote: This article investigates whether the Kampala compromise’s definition of the crime of aggression, as adopted at the 2010 Review Conference and embedded in the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC), can be interpreted to encompass state-sponsored cyberattacks, thereby creating a legal deterrent against acts of cyber-aggression. It begins by tracing the decades-long struggle to define aggression in international law, from the Nuremberg Tribunal’s characterization of aggression as the “supreme international crime” through the placeholder in Article 5(2) of the Rome Statute and the Special Working Group on the Crime of Aggression’s negotiations, culminating in the Kampala compromise’s adoption of key terms—"act of aggression," "manifest violation," and the gravity threshold. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology, the study examines the preparatory travaux of the Special Working Group, analyzes emblematic cyber incidents, and reviews post-Kampala state practice, with particular attention to U.S. cyber doctrine and policy documents. The analysis demonstrates that although the Kampala definitions are conventionally grounded in kinetic warfare paradigms, their language can be flexibly construed by ICC judges to cover cyber operations when assessed by their impact on state sovereignty, threat to international peace, and severity of consequences. However, the article identifies significant jurisdictional and political barriers—namely the primacy of the U.N. Security Council in labeling acts of aggression and the stringent threshold for individual criminal responsibility—which render near-term prosecutions for cyber-aggression unlikely. The author warns that expansive U.S. cyber doctrines risk broadening the ambit of aggression to include routine intelligence gathering or defensive counter-intrusions, potentially influencing customary international law ahead of global consensus. Recognizing these limitations, the article argues for complementary measures to deter and address cyber-aggression, including diplomatic engagement, norm-setting initiatives such as the Tallinn Manual and International Telecommunication Union cyber-peace proposals, international standard-setting for secure network infrastructures, cooperative defensive measures, and information-sharing regimes. It further recommends that U.S. policy be recalibrated to balance normative stability with effective deterrence, and that implementation of non-binding guidance precede the eventual application of individual criminal liability. The study concludes by advocating sustained multidisciplinary efforts—legal, diplomatic, and technical—to preemptively curb cyber-aggression and promote a peaceful cyberspace before hostile acts reach the threshold of armed conflict.

data.title: NATO, cyber defense, and international law
data.abstractNote: This article examines the evolving nexus of cybersecurity threats, collective defense, and international law within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), assessing whether the Alliance can adapt its policies and capabilities in cyberspace before a major crisis undermines its Article 5 obligations. Drawing on a symposium that integrated three expert presentations—covering operational perspectives on NATO’s Computer Incident Response Capability (NCIRC), the legal framework for cyber operations and collective self-defense, and NATO’s doctrinal and legal responses—the authors employ a qualitative legal-political methodology to synthesize policy documents, consensus-based decision-making processes, and landmark case studies, including the 2007 Estonian cyber attacks and the 2013 PRISM disclosures. Part I outlines NATO’s historical evolution from a Cold War collective defense alliance to a security actor confronting nontraditional threats, highlighting how the Alliance’s principles of sovereignty, nonintervention, and unanimous decision-making shape its cyber defense posture. The analysis traces NATO’s operational responses, notably the establishment and mandate of NCIRC, and identifies three overarching policy approaches: a threat-centric framework emphasizing adaptation of legacy legal norms; a defense-centric stance focusing on building resilient architectures; and a technology-centric orientation privileging capability accumulation without due regard for established legal principles. Part II interrogates a policy shift from the dense legal texture of the threat approach toward a capability-driven model, uncovering constraints imposed by conservative legal interpretations, limited technology sharing among member states, and the absence of agreed rules for proactive or offensive cyber measures. Such constraints risk relegating NATO to a static, reactive ‘‘cyber Maginot Line.’’ The article highlights key legal questions regarding state responsibility, jus ad bellum in cyberspace, and the potential need to revise International Law categories as discussed in the Tallinn Manual. It concludes that, although NATO has made foundational strides in articulating a cyber threat approach and operational structures, without consensus on more dynamic defense and offense capabilities—and willingness to adapt legal frameworks—the Alliance will remain reactive. The authors propose future research on empirical evaluation of member-state technology sharing, development of cyber rules of engagement within NATO’s Nuclear Planning Group model, examination of secrecy’s impact on alliance cohesion, and legal reforms to accommodate cyber contingencies, aiming to enable NATO to lead global cybersecurity cooperation rather than trail behind.

data.title: Cyber responsibility to protect: legal obligations of states directly affected by cyber-incidents
data.abstractNote: In “Cyber Responsibility to Protect: Legal Obligations of States Directly Affected by Cyber-Incidents,” Oren Gross develops a comprehensive international legal framework that positions cybersecurity incidents as akin to natural disasters, thereby imposing a duty on directly affected states (DAS) to prevent, mitigate, manage, and recover from cyber-incidents under established principles of international law. Gross begins by mapping the growing centrality and vulnerability of ICT and critical infrastructure systems—including energy, transportation, healthcare, and emergency services—to deliberate or accidental cyber disruptions. He underscores key trends magnifying cyber risk: exponential growth in software complexity, the integration of Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition systems into public networks, and the diffusion of cloud computing across multiple jurisdictions. Turning to legal scholarship, Gross observes that extant literature prioritizes the responsibilities of attack-originating actors while largely ignoring the obligations of victim states. To fill this gap, he introduces the concept of a “cyber responsibility to protect” (cyber‐R2P), analogizing DAS duties to the International Law Commission’s (ILC) draft articles on disaster response. Employing doctrinal analysis of treaties, a comparative review of ILC draft provisions, and case-based examination of state practice and domestic laws, he articulates a tripartite timeline of state duty. Before incidents, DAS must implement risk assessments, robust cyber-hygiene protocols, resilience planning, and legislative measures. During incidents, they owe duties to seek and accept external cooperation, facilitate investigations, avoid arbitrary conditions on assistance, and prevent transboundary harm under human rights and environmental law principles. After incidents, states must enact recovery measures, coordinate international assistance, pursue legislative and judicial reforms to prosecute perpetrators, and institutionalize long-term resilience strategies. Gross further addresses challenges in attributing cyber-attacks, assessing post-incident needs, and ensuring quality control of assistance in an environment where affected states may not recognize attacks or accurately gauge damage. He argues that adapting the ILC’s duties to seek, accept, and facilitate assistance—subject to reasonable, non-arbitrary conditions—can balance state sovereignty with global security demands. Gross concludes that operationalizing cyber-R2P will require international consensus on assistance modalities, standard templates for bilateral and multilateral incident response, and empirical evaluation of domestic reforms. By reframing cyber-incidents within an established disaster relief paradigm, this study lays the groundwork for coherent policy, normative development, and legal obligations that bind states to protect both national and global digital infrastructure.

data.title: The 2014 sony hack and the role of international law
data.abstractNote: In The 2014 Sony Hack and the Role of International Law, Clare Sullivan examines the unprecedented cyber operation against Sony Pictures in November 2014, situating the incident within the framework of international law to determine whether state-linked cyberattacks can constitute breaches of sovereignty, use of force, or even armed attacks that justify countermeasures or anticipatory self-defense. Sullivan begins by contextualizing the 2014 hack amid a record number of data breaches in the United States, emphasizing the distinctive ideological motive and scale of damage inflicted by the Guardians of Peace, an actor widely attributed to North Korea. She reconstructs the sequence of events from June 2014 diplomatic protests by Pyongyang over the film The Interview to the eight subsequent data dumps of over 38 million files, which exposed corporate financials, unreleased films, personal employee data, and trade secrets. Employing a doctrinal methodology grounded in the UN Charter, customary international law (notably the Caroline test), state practice, and the Tallinn Manual, Sullivan evaluates U.S. responses, including targeted sanctions under an executive order and reported disruptions to North Korean internet access. She argues that the attack breached U.S. sovereignty by invading protected cyberspace territory and inflicted harm analogous to physical force, thereby creating a lawful basis for proportional countermeasures under international law without resorting to physical violence. She further contends that, given the sustained and threatening nature of the hack, the United States could have invoked anticipatory self-defense because the operation satisfied criteria of necessity and proportionality by posing an imminent threat. Sullivan’s analysis highlights gaps in existing legal norms—such as the lack of clarity on what constitutes proportional cyber countermeasures or the threshold for “armed attack” in cyberspace—and underscores the need for clearer definitions in future legal frameworks. She observes that, while diplomatic and economic sanctions serve as viable tools, cyber operations of this magnitude demand new international legal thinking to deter and defend against state-linked aggression effectively. In concluding, Sullivan calls for further research to refine criteria for cyber sovereignty, the use of force, and legitimate state responses, and for the development of binding norms that balance state security with protection of civilian infrastructure and individual rights in the evolving domain of cyber conflict.

data.title: Navigating "Jus Ad Bellum" in the Age of Cyber Warfare
data.abstractNote: The advent of increasingly sophisticated cyber attacks has transformed cyberspace into a battleground where nation-states wield computer code as a weapon capable of inflicting physical destruction and destabilizing critical infrastructure. Traditional jus ad bellum principles, which emerged in an era of kinetic warfare, offer scant guidance on when a cyber attack constitutes an unlawful use of force or an armed attack justifying countermeasures under the United Nations Charter. This gap has significant implications for international peace and security, as states struggle to calibrate their strategic and legal responses to digital operations that may cause irreversible harm. Recognizing these challenges, the author sets out to refine the conceptual and doctrinal underpinnings of jus ad bellum in the cyber domain, asking when and under what criteria a cyber operation crosses the threshold into armed conflict. To address this question, the paper adopts a doctrinal methodology grounded in international law scholarship, complemented by analysis of technical cyber security research and case studies of malware campaigns such as Stuxnet and large-scale denial-of-service operations. The author first clarifies definitional ambiguities by contrasting object-based definitions of cyber attack with an instrument-based perspective that emphasizes computer networks as the means by which digital weapons operate. Technical contours—such as malware propagation, reversible versus irreversible damage, attribution difficulties, and the convergence of cyber and physical systems—are examined to inform the legal analysis. Next, the paper critiques leading approaches to assessing cyber attacks under jus ad bellum: instrument-based, target-based, and effects-based models each reveal shortcomings in accommodating the unpredictable scope of malware and the diffuseness of its impacts. Drawing on this critique, the author proposes a novel analytical framework centered on cyber-physical systems, defining an armed cyber attack as one intentionally designed to inflict irreversible disruption or damage on systems that intertwine computing and physical components. This cyber-physical systems approach yields clear criteria: attacks against purely digital targets that are reversible and non-destabilizing do not constitute force, while operations threatening critical infrastructure or causing tangible destruction are deemed armed attacks, thus triggering lawful self-defense. While this framework advances the law’s ability to deter the most dangerous cyber operations and to preserve interstate stability, the author acknowledges practical limitations, including the evidentiary challenges of discerning intent and payload design, as well as the evolving nature of networked technologies that may outpace doctrinal adaptation. The paper concludes by calling for further treaty development and state practice to solidify norms, suggesting future research directions such as refining attribution methodologies, exploring proportionality in cyber countermeasures, and integrating the framework into broader strategic doctrine. By offering an objective, administrable standard that aligns with both legal principles and technological realities, this work aims to guide policymakers and legal practitioners in navigating the complexities of cyber conflict under international law.

data.title: Is Cyberattack the Next Pearl Harbor
data.abstractNote: This chapter provides an in-depth examination of the self-help measures available to victim States in response to unlawful, state-sponsored cyber operations under existing international law, focusing on retorsion, countermeasures, and self-defence. It begins by situating these measures within the broader context of the decentralized enforcement of international law, emphasizing that in the absence of a global enforcement authority, self-help remains indispensable for upholding State obligations. The author defines retorsion as lawful but unfriendly acts—such as diplomatic severance, expulsions, travel bans, or economic restrictions—undertaken to signal displeasure while remaining within legal bounds, and contrasts it with countermeasures, which are otherwise unlawful acts rendered lawful as proportionate responses to internationally wrongful acts. The chapter introduces cyber retorsion, illustrating how States may tacitly encourage or tolerate distributed denial-of-service attacks against adversaries, and analyzes landmark case studies including the 2007 Estonia and 2008 Georgia cyber incidents and Operation Ababil against US financial institutions. In the discussion of countermeasures, the author argues that this modality should be the primary tool for victim States, permitting reversible, proportionate sanctions—such as network blocks or asset freezes—and demonstrates how the conditions set forth in the Articles on State Responsibility (notification, proportionality, non-use of force) legitimize cyber countermeasures, particularly given that most cyber intrusions do not meet the armed attack threshold under the jus ad bellum. The self-defence section reviews jus ad bellum criteria, clarifying that only a narrow subset of cyber operations qualify as armed attacks warranting kinetic or forceful responses, and introduces the “accumulation theory” whereby multiple lower-intensity events might collectively constitute an armed attack. It concludes that countermeasures should serve as the default response to state-sponsored cyber operations, reserving self-defence for exceptional scenarios. The chapter further examines emerging State practice—highlighting the United States’ use of public retorsion through sanctions and covert countermeasures following the Sony Pictures hack and the 2016 DNC intrusion—and warns of potential fragmentation of cyber norms after the impasse at the fifth UN Group of Governmental Experts, underscoring the urgent need to clarify cyber law at both the jus ad bellum and jus in bello levels.

data.title: Peacetime Cyber Responses and Wartime Cyber Operations under International Law: An Analytical Vade Mecum
data.abstractNote: The article addresses the challenge of applying established principles of international law to cyber operations occurring both in peacetime and during armed conflict, highlighting the ambiguity and strategic risks that states face in responding to malicious cyber activities. It emphasizes the significance of clarifying legal frameworks for state responses to harmful cyber operations in the context of rising geopolitical tensions and the prevalence of state-sponsored intrusions, arguing that legal uncertainty may undermine effective deterrence and provoke escalatory dynamics. To address this gap, the author aims to provide government legal advisers and policymakers with a practical analytical roadmap, posing the central question of how to assess cyber incidents against thresholds for self-defense, necessity, and countermeasures, as well as how to interpret targeting rules under international humanitarian law in cyber warfare. Methodologically, the article draws on doctrinal legal analysis grounded in the 154 rules and commentary of Tallinn Manual 2.0, deploying normative legal reasoning and structured flowcharts to translate complex legal norms into a step-by-step vade mecum for practitioners. The first flowchart guides states through the assessment of peacetime cyber operations, delineating criteria for armed attack, self-defense, the plea of necessity, and countermeasures, including attribution, breach of obligation, and proportionality, while the second diagram addresses the classification of cyber activities in armed conflict, covering definitions of attack, target identification, precautions, proportionality, and neutrality obligations. Key findings reveal that although existing international law principles can be applied to cyberspace, their operationalization requires careful parsing of intent, effects, and jurisdictional factors, and that the thresholds for invoking self-defense or countermeasures depend on the severity of harm and immediacy of threat. The article contributes a novel skeleton framework that systematizes the decision-making process, translating abstract rules into actionable steps that can support coherent state practice and strengthen legal deterrence. However, the author acknowledges limitations inherent in this skeletal approach, cautioning that the flowcharts offer only a general vector through a complex legal landscape and may not accommodate every incident’s unique features, and that the nascent state of international cyber law leaves many issues unresolved. For future research, the article underscores the need for empirical studies of state practice and opinio juris to refine legal norms, calls for more granular analysis of emerging gray-zone operations, and suggests that iterative feedback between practice and doctrine will be essential to evolve a robust legal regime governing cyber conflict.

data.title: Cyber-Security beyond the Military Perspective: International Law, 'Cyberspace', and the Concept of Due Diligence Focus: Cyber-Security beyond the Military Perspective
data.abstractNote: States increasingly rely on cyberspace for critical communication, economic transactions, and public services, yet the absence of specific international legal norms governing state behavior in this domain has generated uncertainty and risk. This research addresses the urgent problem of how preexisting rules of international law can regulate harmful state-conduct in cyberspace by examining the general concept of due diligence and its applicability to cyber activities. The study is motivated by the significance of securing an open, stable, and rights-respecting cyberspace in contemporary geopolitics, and asks how due diligence obligations under general international law can be specified to govern state behavior before, during, and after cyber incidents. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology, the authors analyse state practice and opinio juris, relevant United Nations Group of Governmental Experts reports, and established principles from analogous fields such as international environmental law. They examine foundational norms from the UN Charter and state sovereignty, and review outcomes from successive Berlin Cyber Conferences organised by the German Federal Foreign Office. The analysis reveals that international law, including the prohibition of the use of force, the right of self-defence, and principles of state responsibility, fully applies to information and communications technology. Due diligence emerges as a minimum standard against which state conduct may be tested, encompassing both substantive measures—such as preventing misuse of cyber infrastructure under jurisdiction—and procedural measures—such as establishing institutional capacities and points of contact for inter-state cooperation. The authors identify context-specific obligations for origin states to prevent and mitigate harmful cyber operations, for transit states to curb malicious traffic passing through their territory, and for target states to enhance resilience of critical infrastructure and share intelligence. They further clarify that due diligence obligations vary with technical feasibility and economic capacity, implying no uniform set of measures is required of all states. The principal contribution of this study lies in articulating a coherent due diligence framework tailored to cyber-conflict contexts and in proposing guidelines for preventive, responsive, and cooperative state actions. Recognising that due diligence is inherently broad, the authors acknowledge limitations including the vagueness of general legal norms and the lack of consensus on harm thresholds that trigger obligations, as well as potential tensions with privacy rights. They caution that until specific treaty regimes emerge, states must navigate these general obligations, balancing freedom, security, and rule-of-law values. For future research, the authors advocate comparative investigation of international environmental law’s treaty development to inform the creation of a specialized cyber treaty regime, empirical study of state capacity constraints, and exploration of institutional models for enhanced inter-state cooperation in cyberspace governance.

data.title: A Better Defense: Examining the United States' New Norms-Based Approach to Cyber Deterrence International Engagement on Cyber III: State Building on a New Frontier
data.abstractNote: Since 2010, states have confronted the growing challenge of deterring adversarial actions conducted through cyberspace, recognizing that traditional concepts of military deterrence may not readily translate into the digital domain. The United Nations Group of Governmental Experts underscored the need for norms on state behavior in Information and Communication Technologies to reduce collective risk and protect critical infrastructure, framing the debate on cyber conflict as a matter of international security. This article investigates how the United States has pursued a norms-based approach to cyber deterrence, posing the question of whether embedding cyber strategy within a normative framework can enhance stability and restraint among states. By examining official U.S. policy documents—including the 2011 International Strategy for Cyberspace and the Department of Defense’s Strategy for Operating in Cyberspace—alongside theoretical insights from constructivist scholarship on norm emergence and lifecycle, the author employs a qualitative policy analysis methodology enriched by international relations theory and case references to Estonia, Georgia, and the Stuxnet operation. The analysis reveals that while attribution challenges, difficulty in holding adversaries’ assets at risk, and nonstate actor involvement complicate traditional deterrence models, the U.S. norms-based strategy leverages multilateral dialogue and confidence-building measures to socialize expectations regarding acceptable state conduct. This synergy between normative engagement and military capability appears to strengthen general deterrence, imparting predictability to state behaviors and reducing opportunities for miscalculation. The article contributes a conceptual framework that links the stages of norm development—emergence, cascade, and institutionalization—to the potential evolution of norms into binding international law, thereby providing a structure for effective cyber deterrence. It argues that norms can act as “rules of the road” in cyberspace, internalized by actors and reinforced through diplomatic practice, multilateral forums, and state conduct. Notwithstanding these insights, the study acknowledges limitations stemming from the novelty of cyber norms, the uneven participation of states, potential allegations of double standards—especially in light of the U.S. and Israeli Stuxnet operation—and the political mistrust that can hinder consensus. The paucity of empirical data on compliance mechanisms and the unpredictable nature of norm internalization underscore the need for further empirical investigation. Future research should focus on mapping the processes through which specific cyber norms become legally binding, elucidating the mechanisms of compliance, and exploring how confidence-building transparency measures can pave the way for formal international agreements. By advancing an integrated approach to cyber deterrence that combines normative development, international law, and strategic policy, this study offers a novel lens for scholars and policymakers seeking to secure cyberspace through law and shared expectations rather than force alone.

data.title: From the Kalashnikov to the Keyboard: International Law's Failure to Define a Cyber Use of Force is Dangerous and May Lead to a Military Response to a Cyber Use of Force
data.abstractNote: The evolution of cyberspace as a fifth domain of warfare has outpaced the development of a coherent international legal framework, creating a critical gap in addressing cyber operations that may not constitute armed attacks yet still pose significant threats to states. This article sets forth the problem that international law’s current use of art. 2(4) of the UN Charter and the jus ad bellum and jus in bello frameworks inadequately encompasses “cyber uses of force” and “uses of cyber coercion,” leaving a structural fragility that risks uncontrolled escalation or even a military response to state-sponsored cyber activity. The author justifies this inquiry by pointing to high-profile incidents such as the Sony Pictures operation and Stuxnet that demonstrate both the increasing frequency and escalating destructive potential of cyber operations; the article aims to reconceptualize cyber discourse, define these categories of cyber activity, and propose mechanisms by which the international community can preemptively regulate them. Methodologically, the research employs a doctrinal legal analysis grounded in the Charter of the United Nations, a critical literature review of scholarly definitions of “cyber war,” and a case study examination of the Sony Pictures hack to illustrate the insufficiencies of existing norms and response options. The findings reveal that states have neither expressly nor implicitly extended art. 2(4) to include all cyber operations amounting to force or coercion, that the rhetorical prevalence of terms like “cyber war” may license overly broad national responses, and that most cyber operations fall short of armed attack thresholds yet nonetheless undermine political independence or territorial integrity. As a contribution, the author proposes a novel “Cyber Kellogg–Briand Pact” framework, modeled on the 1928 Pact’s renunciation of war, which would formally define “cyber uses of force” and “uses of cyber coercion,” stigmatize their employment as instruments of policy, clarify lawful countermeasures, and prohibit military responses to coercive cyber operations. The article acknowledges limitations inherent in a treaty analogous to the original Kellogg–Briand Pact, including potential non-signatory states, the exclusion of self-defense parameters, and the challenge of enforcing soft-law commitments; it also recognizes that its doctrinal focus may not capture all technical nuances of cyber capability development. For future research, the author suggests refining the proposed treaty’s parameters to address self-defense, elaborating compliance mechanisms for non-signatories, integrating technical thresholds for destructive potential, and studying the impact of naming and shaming practices on state behavior in cyberspace. This work lays the groundwork for a preventive normative architecture capable of stabilizing state conduct in cyber conflict before a destructive “true event” compels reactive legal development.

data.title: Restating the Law as It Is: On the Tallinn Manual and the Use of Force in Cyberspace
data.abstractNote: The growing prominence of cyberspace as a domain of state confrontation has catalyzed intense debate over whether and how existing international law governs cyber operations amounting to the use of force. This study examines the Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare, a leading expert restatement aiming to apply jus ad bellum norms, particularly Article 2(4) of the UN Charter, to cyber operations. Recognizing that ambiguity persists over whether and how the prohibition on the use of force applies to actions that lack physical destruction or loss of life, the research asks how the Manual’s so-called ‘‘Schmitt criteria’’ should be understood in relation to existing law. It seeks to determine whether these criteria reflect lex lata, propose lex ferenda, constitute new treaty or customary rules, or function merely as political tools influencing state assessments. Employing a doctrinal legal methodology, the article undertakes a close textual analysis of the Manual’s introduction, Rule 11 and commentary, supplemented by key scholarly works and decisional sources. The analysis traces the Manual’s historical lineage from early normative frameworks, through Schmitt’s six criteria, to the Manual’s presentation of eight ‘‘factors’’ states ‘‘are likely to consider’’ when characterizing cyber operations as uses of force. It finds that the criteria lack substantiation in any primary source of international law—treaty, custom or general principles—and that the Manual’s self-professed intent to ‘‘restat[e] the law as it is’’ clashes with its reliance on nonlegal, predictive considerations. Nor does the Manual advocate for treaty formation or customary crystallization, instead depicting the factors as non-binding, context-dependent guides. Yet labeling them political tools overlooks their normative effect: application of the criteria directly influences determinations of state responsibility, reparation, and prospective countermeasures. By conflating ‘‘predictive’’ with ‘‘normative’’ processes, the Manual inadvertently undermines the prescriptive clarity it promises. This critique contributes a systematic typology of possible legal statuses for the criteria and reveals the Manual’s interpretative effort as more than mere law application, occupying a quasi-legislative space that deepens rather than resolves legal indeterminacy. Acknowledging its focus on textual analysis and the limited corpus of state practice available, the article calls for empirical research into how states actually invoke the criteria in diplomatic and legal fora, comparative study of analogous doctrinal evolutions in economic coercion law, and exploration of alternative normative instruments—such as treaties or a cyber-specific dispute resolution mechanism—to address the inherent indeterminacy of Article 2(4) when applied to cyber operations.
